diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +36,40 @@- Person making the proposal creates the proposal document in ansible/docs/proposals via PR, following the proposal template.
- Author of proposal PR updates the proposal with the PR # / link.
- Notify the community that this proposal exists.
- Author notifies ansible-devel mailing list for transparency, providing link to PR.
- Author includes commentary indicating that comments should *not* be in response to this email, but rather, community members should add comments or feedback to the pull request.

comments.body:
Do we worry that this directory will become cluttered with completed proposals over time? Maybe we should move them to a different directory upon completion? Like, maybe, "specs" or something?

Also: we will want to pass on some proposals, I assume. Should they be in some other directory as well?

In the case of the "roadmap directory", should that exist: Possibly. I think ideally we might have a directory (it could be called specs, or roadmap, or ???) for each release, or perhaps one called "current" and then past release numbers. 

Proposals that are passed on, abandoned, put on hold / deferred to the future,  etc. could each have their own directory, yes. 

One thing to consider is whether or not we want to clutter up the tree with all of this for all releases forever, or archive things to some other historical location.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +61,65 @@5: CODE COMPLETE
- Proposal document, which should be in docs/roadmap, should have their status updated to COMPLETE.
- The release notes file for the targeted release should be updated with a small note regarding the feature or enhancement; completed proposals for community processes should have a follow-up mail sent to the mailing list providing information and links to the new process.
- Hooray! Buy your friend a tasty beverage of their choosing.

comments.body: Again, we need some kind of bucket for "rejected".

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +74,78 @@- Date:

- Status: New, Approved, Pending, Complete
- Proposal type: Feature  / enhancement / community development process
- Targeted Release:

comments.body:
Maybe? Feature vs. enhancement could mean different things in terms of the scope of the projects, whether or not it is digging into existing code and making changes vs. adding a lot of new code. Or it could be the differentiator between "goes in release notes and marketing things, or not." We could just assume for now that features and enhancements are all just enhancements, and if we find that we need further clarity in the future, figure it out later.

I think it's useful to split out community-related processes, such as this one; they're not necessarily things that need to be in a roadmap or release notes. And may be useful to store in a separate place from roadmap / specs after approval / implementation, so folks can easily see how things evolved. But I'm not married to the idea by any means. :bride_with_veil:
